explanation:
To decide whether any portion of internal_add_connection is statically unreachable you must know which conditional/compile-time controls can be true or removed and whether called helpers can force an early return. Briefly:

- MHD_D_IS_USING_SELECT_: Controls the first if — if this macro is a compile-/constant expression always false (or always true) the whole select branch may be unreachable (or the condition reduced).
- MHD_D_DOES_SCKT_FIT_FDSET_: The second operand of the select-if; needed to know whether that branch can evaluate true at run-time (or be a constant) so the body (socket-close/return) is reachable.
- MHD_D_GET_FD_SETSIZE_: Used only in the debug message but part of the select-check family; its definition may indicate compile-time constness relevant to reachability of the surrounding code or diagnostics.
- MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_: Controls the epoll-mode if — if this macro cannot be true (or is constant) the epoll error branch may be unreachable.
- MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_: Governs the external_add + thread-safe branch; if this predicate is impossible for any daemon instance then that whole block is unreachable.
- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_: Controls whether the inter-thread-communication signalling code can be entered; a constant false would make the inner block unreachable.
- MHD_itc_activate_: Its return value is used in a condition: if this routine can never return false (or always does) it affects reachability of the diagnostic-path inside that conditional.
- new_connection_prepare_: This call can return NULL and the function returns immediately if so. To determine whether code after the call (including the external_add branch and final return) can ever be reached you need its semantics/implementation (or at least its possible return values).
- new_connection_process_: The final call executed when processing proceeds; knowing whether new_connection_process_ is a macro with nonlocal control transfer or a function that never returns (or always returns) matters for reachability reasoning of any code following its invocation (and for total path coverage analysis).
- struct MHD_Daemon: The macros above are typically implemented in terms of fields in struct MHD_Daemon (e.g. mode flags, itc, worker_pool). You need the daemon struct definition to evaluate whether the predicates can be true/false for any valid daemon instance.
- HAVE_MESSAGES: A preprocessor symbol that controls inclusion of logging calls inside branches. Whether those logging statements are compiled in affects whether code exists in those branches (preprocessor removal can create/avoid unreachable statements).
- MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS and MHD_USE_W32_THREADS: These preprocessor symbols control the initial assert block. Their presence/absence alters the compiled function body and thus what code is present or possibly unreachable.
- ENFILE and EINVAL: Preprocessor presence controls whether errno assignments are compiled into the branch bodies; compilation-time absence/presence changes the exact code that must be considered for reachability.

Collectively these symbols determine which branches exist in the compiled function and whether the conditional expressions can be satisfied at compile-time or runtime. They are therefore necessary to conclude whether any statements in internal_add_connection are (statically) unreachable for MISRA C rule analysis.
